template.template: Template Microsoft SQL Server DE Tier 1
template.name: Template Microsoft SQL Server DE Tier 1
template.description:
Zabbix template for Microsoft SQL Server.
Tested on Microsoft SQL Server 2012, 2014, 2016 and 2019. It may work with earlier versions, but some items (with missing performance counters) may be unsupported. Tested on Zabbix 3.4.0. and 4.0.0. It may work with earlier versions, but some items (for example service.info[service,<param>]) may be unsupported.
For Low Level Discovery to work additional scripts must be configured.
Mantas Tumenas. mantas.tumenas@gmail.com

discovery_rule.name: SQL Server Databases Discovery
discovery_rule.description: SQL Server database discovery with additional scripts lets discover Microsoft SQL Server databases.

item_prototype.name: SQL Instance {#SQLINSTANCENAME} Database {#DBNAME}: Active Transactions
item_prototype.description: Number of active transactions for the database.

item_prototype.name: SQL Instance {#SQLINSTANCENAME} Database {#DBNAME}: Log Bytes Flushed/sec
item_prototype.description:
Total number of log bytes flushed.
Useful for determining trends and utilization of the transaction log

item_prototype.name: SQL Instance {#SQLINSTANCENAME} Database {#DBNAME}: Log Flushes/sec
item_prototype.description: Number of log flushes.

item_prototype.name: SQL Instance {#SQLINSTANCENAME} Database {#DBNAME}: Log Flush Waits/sec
item_prototype.description:
Number of commits per second waiting for the log flush.
Effectively, the number of times per second that SQL Server must wait for pages to be written to the transaction log.

item_prototype.name: SQL Instance {#SQLINSTANCENAME} Database {#DBNAME}: Log Flush Wait Time
item_prototype.description:
Total wait time (in milliseconds) to flush the log.
On an AlwaysOn secondary database, this value indicates the wait time for log records to be hardened to disk.

item_prototype.name: SQL Instance {#SQLINSTANCENAME} Database {#DBNAME}: Log Growths
item_prototype.description:
Total number of times the transaction log for the database has been expanded.
Each time the transaction log grows, all user activity must halt until the log growth completes. Therefore, you want log growths to occur during predefined maintenance windows rather than during general working hours.

item_prototype.name: SQL Instance {#SQLINSTANCENAME} Database {#DBNAME}: Log Shrinks
item_prototype.description: Total number of times the transaction log for the database has been shrunk.

item_prototype.name: SQL Instance {#SQLINSTANCENAME} Database {#DBNAME}: Log Truncations
item_prototype.description:
Number of times the transaction log has been shrunk.
Truncations should happen during log backups or, on databases in simple recovery mode, at checkpoint or the time period specified by recovery interval.

trigger_prototype.expression: {Template Microsoft SQL Server DE Tier 1:perf_counter["\{#SQLINSTANCE}:Databases({#DBNAME})\Log Flush Waits/sec"].last(0)}>0
trigger_prototype.name: SQL Instance {#SQLINSTANCENAME} Database {#DBNAME}: Log Flush Waits/sec {ITEM.LASTVALUE}
trigger_prototype.description:
Number of commits per second waiting for the log flush.
Effectively, the number of times per second that SQL Server must wait for pages to be written to the transaction log.

trigger_prototype.expression: {Template Microsoft SQL Server DE Tier 1:perf_counter["\{#SQLINSTANCE}:Databases({#DBNAME})\Log Flush Wait Time"].last(0)}>100
trigger_prototype.name: SQL Instance {#SQLINSTANCENAME} Database {#DBNAME}: Log Flush Wait Time {ITEM.LASTVALUE}
trigger_prototype.description: Total wait time (in milliseconds) to flush the log. On an AlwaysOn secondary database, this value indicates the wait time for log records to be hardened to disk.

trigger_prototype.expression: {Template Microsoft SQL Server DE Tier 1:perf_counter["\{#SQLINSTANCE}:Databases({#DBNAME})\Log Growths"].diff(0)}>1
trigger_prototype.name: SQL Instance {#SQLINSTANCENAME} Database {#DBNAME}: Log Growths > 0
trigger_prototype.description:
Total number of times the transaction log for the database has been expanded.
Each time the transaction log grows, all user activity must halt until the log growth completes. Therefore, you want log growths to occur during predefined maintenance windows rather than during general working hours.

trigger_prototype.expression: {Template Microsoft SQL Server DE Tier 1:perf_counter["\{#SQLINSTANCE}:Databases({#DBNAME})\Log Shrinks"].change(86400)}=1
trigger_prototype.name: SQL Instance {#SQLINSTANCENAME} Database {#DBNAME}: Log Was Shrinked In The Last 24 Hours
trigger_prototype.description: Total number of times the transaction log for the database has been shrunk.

discovery_rule.name: SQL Server Instances Discovery
discovery_rule.description: SQL Server instances discovery with additional scripts lets discover Microsoft SQL Server instances.

item_prototype.name: SQL Instance {#SQLINSTANCENAME}: Forwarded Records/sec
item_prototype.description:
Number of records per second fetched through forwarded record pointers.
Identifies use of a pointer which has been created when variable length columns have caused a row to move to a new page in a heap.

item_prototype.name: SQL Instance {#SQLINSTANCENAME}: Full Scans/sec
item_prototype.description:
Number of unrestricted full scans. These can either be base table or full index scans.
Monitors the number of full scans on tables or indexes. Ignore unless high CPU coincides with high scan rates. High scan rates may be caused by missing indexes, very small tables, or requests for too many records.
Threshold: a sudden increase in this value may indicate a statistics threshold has been reached, resulting in an index no longer being used.

item_prototype.name: SQL Instance {#SQLINSTANCENAME}: Index Searches/sec
item_prototype.description:
Number of index searches. Index searches are used to start range scans, single index record fetches, and to reposition within an index.
The threshold recommendation is strictly for OLTP workloads.

item_prototype.name: SQL Instance {#SQLINSTANCENAME}: Page Splits/sec
item_prototype.description:
Number of page splits per second that occur as a result of overflowing index pages.
To avoid page splits, review table and index design to reduce non-sequential inserts or implement fillfactor and pad_index to leave more empty space per page. NOTE: A high value for this counter is not bad in situations where many new pages are being created, since it includes new page allocations.
Threshold: should be as low as possible.

item_prototype.name: SQL Instance {#SQLINSTANCENAME}: Table Lock Escalations/sec
item_prototype.description:
The number of times locks on a table were escalated (from page- or row-level to table-level).
Threshold: this number should, generally, be low. Frequent or even occasional spiking in this value may indicate poorly coded transactions.

item_prototype.name: SQL Instance {#SQLINSTANCENAME}: Workfiles Created/sec
item_prototype.description:
Number of work files created per second. For example, work files could be used to store temporary results for hash joins and hash aggregates.
Threshold: high values can indicate thrash in tempdb and poorly coded queries.

item_prototype.name: SQL Instance {#SQLINSTANCENAME}: Worktables Created/sec
item_prototype.description: Number of work tables created per second. For example, work tables could be used to store temporary results for query spool, LOB variables, XML variables, and cursors.

item_prototype.name: SQL Instance {#SQLINSTANCENAME}: Checkpoint Pages/sec
item_prototype.description:
Number of pages flushed by checkpoint or other operations that require all dirty pages to be flushed.
Checkpoint frequency is influenced by the recovery interval setting in sp_configure.
Threshold: high values for this counter may indicate insufficient memory or that the recovery interval is too high.

item_prototype.name: SQL Instance {#SQLINSTANCENAME}: Database Pages
item_prototype.description:
Number of pages in the buffer pool with database content.
As opposed to other usages for memory such as free pages, procedure cache, etc.

item_prototype.name: SQL Instance {#SQLINSTANCENAME}: Page Lookups/sec
item_prototype.description:
Number of requests to find a page in the buffer pool.
Threshold: when the ratio of batch requests to page lookups crests 100, you may have inefficient execution plans or too many adhoc queries.

item_prototype.name: SQL Instance {#SQLINSTANCENAME}: Active Cursors _Total
item_prototype.description:
Number of active cursors.
Threshold: a heavy use of server cursors can result in performance issues.

item_prototype.name: SQL Instance {#SQLINSTANCENAME}: User Connections
item_prototype.description:
Number of users connected to the system.
Threshold: this counter should roughly track with Batch Requests/Sec. They should generally rise and fall together. For example, blocking problems could be revealed by rising user connections, lock waits and lock wait time coupled with declining batch requests/sec.

item_prototype.name: SQL Instance {#SQLINSTANCENAME}: Average Latch Wait Time (ms)
item_prototype.description:
Average latch wait time (in milliseconds) for latch requests that had to wait.
Threshold: this value should generally correlate to Latch Waits/sec and move up or down with it accordingly.

item_prototype.name: SQL Instance {#SQLINSTANCENAME}: Latch Waits/sec
item_prototype.description:
Number of latch requests that could not be granted immediately and had to wait before being granted.
Latches are lightweight means of holding a very transient server resource, such as an address in memory.

item_prototype.name: SQL Instance {#SQLINSTANCENAME}: Total Latch Wait Time (ms)
item_prototype.description:
Total latch wait time (in milliseconds) for latch requests that had to wait in the last second.
Threshold: this value should stay stable compared to the number of latch waits per second.

item_prototype.name: SQL Instance {#SQLINSTANCENAME}: Average Lock Wait Time (ms) (_Total)
item_prototype.description:
The average amount of wait time (in milliseconds) for each lock request that resulted in a wait.
Threshold: an average wait time longer than 500ms may indicate excessive blocking. This value should generally correlate to Lock Waits/sec and move up or down with it accordingly.

item_prototype.name: SQL Instance {#SQLINSTANCENAME}: Lock Requests/sec (_Total)
item_prototype.description:
Number of new locks and lock conversions requested from the lock manager.
Threshold: this metrics value should generally correspond to Batch Requests/sec. Values > 1000 may indicate queries are accessing very large numbers of rows and may benefit from tuning.

item_prototype.name: SQL Instance {#SQLINSTANCENAME}: Lock Timeouts/sec (_Total)
item_prototype.description:
Number of lock requests that timed out. This includes requests for NOWAIT locks.
Threshold: a value greater than zero might indicate that user queries are not completing. The lower this value is, the better.

item_prototype.name: SQL Instance {#SQLINSTANCENAME}: Lock Waits/sec (_Total)
item_prototype.description:
Number of lock requests that could not be satisfied immediately and required the caller to wait before being granted the lock.
Threshold: values greater than zero indicate at least some blocking is occurring, while a value of zero can quickly eliminate blocking as a potential root-cause problem. As with Lock Wait Time, lock waits are not recorded by Performance Monitor until after the lock event completes.

item_prototype.name: SQL Instance {#SQLINSTANCENAME}: Lock Wait Time (ms) (_Total)
item_prototype.description:
Total wait time (in milliseconds) for locks in the last second.
Threshold: because SQL Server records a lock at the end of a locking event, remember that an application with huge transactions may have inflated lock wait times while still performing as expected. For example, an application that issues multi-million record updates might have very long lock wait times while performing exactly as it was designed.

item_prototype.name: SQL Instance {#SQLINSTANCENAME}: Number of Deadlocks/sec (_Total)
item_prototype.description:
Number of lock requests that resulted in a deadlock.
Threshold: since only a COMMIT, ROLLBACK, or deadlock can terminate a transaction (excluding failures or errors), this is an important value to track. Excessive deadlocking indicates a table or index design error or bad application design.

item_prototype.name: SQL Instance {#SQLINSTANCENAME}: Granted Workspace Memory (KB)
item_prototype.description: Total amount of memory granted to executing processes. This memory is used for hash, sort and create index operations.

item_prototype.name: SQL Instance {#SQLINSTANCENAME}: Maximum Workspace Memory (KB)
item_prototype.description: Total amount of memory available for grants to executing processes. This memory is used primarily for hash, sort and create index operations.

item_prototype.name: SQL Instance {#SQLINSTANCENAME}: Memory Grants Outstanding
item_prototype.description: Current number of processes that have successfully acquired a workspace memory grant

item_prototype.name: SQL Instance {#SQLINSTANCENAME}: Memory Grants Pending
item_prototype.description:
Current number of processes waiting for a workspace memory grant.
Threshold: numbers higher than 0 indicate a lack of memory.

item_prototype.name: SQL Instance {#SQLINSTANCENAME}: Cache Hit Ratio (_Total)
item_prototype.description:
Ratio between cache hits and lookups.
This deals with the procedure cache. This indicates how many query plans exist in the cache vs how many were compiled at run time.
Threshold: this number starts very low after the system restart and should consistently stay close to 95-100%.

item_prototype.name: SQL Instance {#SQLINSTANCENAME}: Cache Pages
item_prototype.description:
Number of 8k pages used by cache objects.
This deals with the procedure cache and tells how many 8 KB pages are used for the procedure cache.
Threshold: Low value of combination Cache Hit Ratio coupled with high number of Cache Pages, tells that the system might be suffering from dynamic sql issues.

item_prototype.name: SQL Instance {#SQLINSTANCENAME}: Errors/sec Info Errors
item_prototype.description: Number of info errors.

item_prototype.name: SQL Instance {#SQLINSTANCENAME}: Errors/sec Kill Connection Errors
item_prototype.description:
Number of errors per second which cause SQL Server to kill a user connection, respectively.
Threshold: since these are severe errors, they should occur very infrequently.

item_prototype.name: SQL Instance {#SQLINSTANCENAME}: Errors/sec User Errors
item_prototype.description: Number of user errors.

item_prototype.name: SQL Instance {#SQLINSTANCENAME}: Auto-Param Attempts/sec
item_prototype.description:
Number of auto-parameterization attempts per second.
Total should be the sum of the failed, safe, and unsafe auto-parameterizations. Auto-parameterization occurs when an instance of SQL Server tries to parameterize a Transact-SQL request by replacing some literals with parameters so that reuse of the resulting cached execution plan across multiple similar-looking requests is possible. Note that auto-parameterizations are also known as simple parameterizations in newer versions of SQL Server. This counter does not include forced parameterizations.

item_prototype.name: SQL Instance {#SQLINSTANCENAME}: Batch Requests/Sec
item_prototype.description:
Number of SQL batch requests received by server.
This counter is highly dependent on the hardware and quality of code running on the server. The more powerful the hardware, the higher this number can be, even on poorly coded applications. A value of 1000 batch requests/sec is easily attainable though a typical 100Mbs NIC can only handle about 3000 batch requests/sec. Many other counter thresholds depend upon batch requests/sec while, in some cases, a low (or high) number does not point to poor processing power. You should frequently use this counter in combination with other counters, such as processor utilization or user connections.

item_prototype.name: SQL Instance {#SQLINSTANCENAME}: Failed Auto-Params/sec
item_prototype.description:
Number of failed auto-parameterizations.
Threshold: this should be small. Note that auto-parameterizations are also known as simple parameterizations in later versions of SQL Server.

item_prototype.name: SQL Instance {#SQLINSTANCENAME}: Safe Auto-Params/sec
item_prototype.description:
Number of safe auto-parameterizations.
Safe refers to a determination that a cached execution plan can be shared between different similar-looking Transact-SQL statements. SQL Server makes many auto-parameterization attempts some of which turn out to be safe and others fail. Note that auto-parameterizations are also known as simple parameterizations in later versions of SQL Server. This does not include forced parameterizations.

item_prototype.name: SQL Instance {#SQLINSTANCENAME}: SQL Attention Rate/sec
item_prototype.description:
Number of attentions per second.
An attention is a request by the client to end the currently running request or the query timeouts occurring per second.
Threshold: this number should be as low as possible. A high sustained number indicates frequent query timeout or end-user cancellation of queries.

item_prototype.name: SQL Instance {#SQLINSTANCENAME}: SQL Compilations/sec
item_prototype.description:
Number of SQL compilations.
Threshold: the lower this value is the better. High values often indicate excessive adhoc querying and should be as low as possible. If excessive adhoc querying is happening, try rewriting the queries as procedures or invoke the queries using sp_executeSQL. When rewriting isnt possible, consider using a plan guide or setting the database to parameterization forced mode.

item_prototype.name: SQL Instance {#SQLINSTANCENAME}: SQL Re-Compilations/sec
item_prototype.description:
Number of SQL re-compiles.
Threshold: this number should be at or near zero, since recompiles can cause deadlocks and exclusive compile locks. This counters value should follow in proportion to Batch Requests/sec and SQL Compilations/sec. This needs to be nil in your system as much as possible.

item_prototype.name: SQL Instance {#SQLINSTANCENAME}: Unsafe Auto-Params/sec
item_prototype.description:
Number of unsafe auto-parameterizations.
For example, the query has some characteristics that prevent the cached plan from being shared. These are designated as unsafe. This does not count the number of forced parameterizations.

item_prototype.name: SQL Instance {#SQLINSTANCENAME}: Longest Transaction RunningTime
item_prototype.description:
The longest running time of any transaction in seconds.
This counter only shows activity when the database is under read committed snapshot isolation level. It does not log any activity if the database is in any other isolation level.
Threshold: when blocking is high, check this counter to see if transactions are open for long periods of time.

trigger_prototype.expression: {Template Microsoft SQL Server DE Tier 1:perf_counter["\{#SQLINSTANCE}:Locks(_Total)\Average Wait Time (ms)"].last(,0)}>500
trigger_prototype.name: SQL Instance {#SQLINSTANCENAME}: Avg Wait Time (ms) {ITEM.LASTVALUE}
trigger_prototype.description:
The average amount of wait time (in milliseconds) for each lock request that resulted in a wait.
Threshold: an average wait time longer than 500ms may indicate excessive blocking. This value should generally correlate to Lock Waits/sec and move up or down with it accordingly.

trigger_prototype.expression: {Template Microsoft SQL Server DE Tier 1:perf_counter["\{#SQLINSTANCE}:SQL Errors(Info Errors)\Errors/sec"].last(,0)}>0
trigger_prototype.name: SQL Instance {#SQLINSTANCENAME}: Errors/sec Info Errors {ITEM.LASTVALUE}
trigger_prototype.description: Number of info errors.

trigger_prototype.expression: {Template Microsoft SQL Server DE Tier 1:perf_counter["\{#SQLINSTANCE}:SQL Errors(Kill Connection Errors)\Errors/sec"].last(,0)}>0
trigger_prototype.name: SQL Instance {#SQLINSTANCENAME}: Errors/sec Kill Connection Errors {ITEM.LASTVALUE}
trigger_prototype.description:
Number of errors per second which cause SQL Server to kill a user connection, respectively.
Threshold: since these are severe errors, they should occur very infrequently.

trigger_prototype.expression: {Template Microsoft SQL Server DE Tier 1:perf_counter["\{#SQLINSTANCE}:SQL Errors(User Errors)\Errors/sec"].last(0)}>0
trigger_prototype.name: SQL Instance {#SQLINSTANCENAME}: Errors/sec User Errors {ITEM.LASTVALUE}
trigger_prototype.description: Number of user errors.

trigger_prototype.expression: ({Template Microsoft SQL Server DE Tier 1:perf_counter["\{#SQLINSTANCE}:Access Methods\Forwarded Records/sec"].avg(604800,0)} / {Template Microsoft SQL Server DE Tier 1:perf_counter["\{#SQLINSTANCE}:SQL Statistics\Batch Requests/Sec"].avg(604800,0)})>0.1
trigger_prototype.name: SQL Instance {#SQLINSTANCENAME}: Forwarded Records/sec / Batch Records/sec avg value > 10% in the last 7 days
trigger_prototype.description:
Identifies use of a pointer which has been created when variable length columns have caused a row to move to a new page in a heap.
Threshold: < 10 Forwarded Records/sec per 100 Batch Requests/sec.

trigger_prototype.expression: ({Template Microsoft SQL Server DE Tier 1:perf_counter["\{#SQLINSTANCE}:Access Methods\Full Scans/sec"].avg(604800,0)} / {Template Microsoft SQL Server DE Tier 1:perf_counter["\{#SQLINSTANCE}:Access Methods\Index Searches/sec"].avg(604800,0)})>0.001
trigger_prototype.name: SQL Instance {#SQLINSTANCENAME}: Full Scans/sec / Index Searches/sec {ITEM.LASTVALUE} %
trigger_prototype.description:
Threshold: < 1 Full Scan/sec per 1000 Index Searches/sec.
The threshold recommendation is strictly for OLTP workloads.

trigger_prototype.expression: {Template Microsoft SQL Server DE Tier 1:perf_counter["\{#SQLINSTANCE}:Locks(_Total)\Lock Requests/sec"].last(,0)}>1000
trigger_prototype.name: SQL Instance {#SQLINSTANCENAME}: Lock Requests/sec {ITEM.LASTVALUE}
trigger_prototype.description:
Number of new locks and lock conversions requested from the lock manager.
Threshold: this metrics value should generally correspond to Batch Requests/sec. Values > 1000 may indicate queries are accessing very large numbers of rows and may benefit from tuning.

trigger_prototype.expression: {Template Microsoft SQL Server DE Tier 1:perf_counter["\{#SQLINSTANCE}:Locks(_Total)\Lock Timeouts/sec"].last(,0)}>1
trigger_prototype.name: SQL Instance {#SQLINSTANCENAME}: Lock Timeouts/sec (_Total) {ITEM.LASTVALUE}
trigger_prototype.description:
Number of lock requests that timed out. This includes requests for NOWAIT locks.
Threshold: a value greater than zero might indicate that user queries are not completing. The lower this value is, the better.

trigger_prototype.expression: {Template Microsoft SQL Server DE Tier 1:perf_counter["\{#SQLINSTANCE}:Locks(_Total)\Lock Waits/sec"].last(0)}>0
trigger_prototype.name: SQL Instance {#SQLINSTANCENAME}: Lock Waits/sec {ITEM.LASTVALUE}
trigger_prototype.description:
Number of lock requests that could not be satisfied immediately and required the caller to wait before being granted the lock.
Threshold: values greater than zero indicate at least some blocking is occurring, while a value of zero can quickly eliminate blocking as a potential root-cause problem. As with Lock Wait Time, lock waits are not recorded by Performance Monitor until after the lock event completes.

trigger_prototype.expression: {Template Microsoft SQL Server DE Tier 1:perf_counter["\{#SQLINSTANCE}:Transactions\Longest Transaction Running Time"].last(,0)}>3600
trigger_prototype.name: SQL Instance {#SQLINSTANCENAME}: Longest Transaction Running Time {ITEM.LASTVALUE}
trigger_prototype.description:
The longest running time of any transaction in seconds.
This counter only shows activity when the database is under read committed snapshot isolation level. It does not log any activity if the database is in any other isolation level.
Threshold: when blocking is high, check this counter to see if transactions are open for long periods of time.

trigger_prototype.expression: {Template Microsoft SQL Server DE Tier 1:perf_counter["\{#SQLINSTANCE}:Locks(_Total)\Number of Deadlocks/sec"].last(,0)}>1
trigger_prototype.name: SQL Instance {#SQLINSTANCENAME}: Number of Deadlocks/sec (_Total) {ITEM.LASTVALUE}
trigger_prototype.description:
Number of lock requests that resulted in a deadlock.
Threshold: since only a COMMIT, ROLLBACK, or deadlock can terminate a transaction (excluding failures or errors), this is an important value to track. Excessive deadlocking indicates a table or index design error or bad application design.

trigger_prototype.expression: ({Template Microsoft SQL Server DE Tier 1:perf_counter["\{#SQLINSTANCE}:Buffer Manager\Page Lookups/sec"].avg(604800,0)} / {Template Microsoft SQL Server DE Tier 1:perf_counter["\{#SQLINSTANCE}:SQL Statistics\Batch Requests/Sec"].avg(604800,0)})>0.85
trigger_prototype.name: SQL Instance {#SQLINSTANCENAME}: Page Lookups/sec / Batch Requests/sec avg value > 100% in the last 7 days
trigger_prototype.description:
Number of requests to find a page in the buffer pool.
Threshold: when the ratio of batch requests to page lookups crests 100, you may have inefficient execution plans or too many adhoc queries.

trigger_prototype.expression: ({Template Microsoft SQL Server DE Tier 1:perf_counter["\{#SQLINSTANCE}:Access Methods\Page Splits/sec"].avg(604800,0)} / {Template Microsoft SQL Server DE Tier 1:perf_counter["\{#SQLINSTANCE}:SQL Statistics\Batch Requests/Sec"].avg(604800,0)})>0.2
trigger_prototype.name: SQL Instance {#SQLINSTANCENAME}: Page Splits/sec / Batch Requests/sec avg value > 20% in the last 7 days
trigger_prototype.description:
Number of page splits per second that occur as a result of overflowing index pages.
To avoid page splits, review table and index design to reduce non-sequential inserts or implement fillfactor and pad_index to leave more empty space per page. NOTE: A high value for this counter is not bad in situations where many new pages are being created, since it includes new page allocations.
Threshold: should be as low as possible. < 20 Page Splits/sec per 100 Batch Requests/sec.

trigger_prototype.expression: {Template Microsoft SQL Server DE Tier 1:perf_counter["\{#SQLINSTANCE}:SQL Statistics\SQL Attention Rate"].last(0)}>0
trigger_prototype.name: SQL Instance {#SQLINSTANCENAME}: SQL Attention Rate/sec {ITEM.LASTVALUE}
trigger_prototype.description:
Number of attentions per second.
An attention is a request by the client to end the currently running request or the query timeouts occurring per second.
Threshold: this number should be as low as possible. A high sustained number indicates frequent query timeout or end-user cancellation of queries.

trigger_prototype.expression: ({Template Microsoft SQL Server DE Tier 1:perf_counter["\{#SQLINSTANCE}:SQL Statistics\SQL Compilations/sec"].avg(604800,0)} / {Template Microsoft SQL Server DE Tier 1:perf_counter["\{#SQLINSTANCE}:SQL Statistics\Batch Requests/Sec"].avg(604800,0)})>0.1
trigger_prototype.name: SQL Instance {#SQLINSTANCENAME}: SQL Compilations/sec / Batch Requests/sec avg value > 10% in the last 7 days
trigger_prototype.description:
Number of times that Transact-SQL compilations occurred, per second (including recompiles). The lower this value is the better. High values often indicate excessive adhoc querying and should be as low as possible. If excessive adhoc querying is happening, try rewriting the queries as procedures or invoke the queries using sp_executeSQL. When rewriting isnt possible, consider using a plan guide or setting the database to parameterization forced mode.
Threshold: SQL Compilations/sec < 10% of the number of Batch Requests/sec.

trigger_prototype.expression: ({Template Microsoft SQL Server DE Tier 1:perf_counter["\{#SQLINSTANCE}:SQL Statistics\SQL Re-Compilations/sec"].avg(3600,0)} / {Template Microsoft SQL Server DE Tier 1:perf_counter["\{#SQLINSTANCE}:SQL Statistics\SQL Compilations/sec"].avg(3600,0)})>0.1
trigger_prototype.name: SQL Instance {#SQLINSTANCENAME}: SQL Re-Compilations/sec / SQL Compilations/sec avg value > 10% in the last 60 min
trigger_prototype.description:
Number of times, per second, that Transact-SQL objects attempted to be executed but had to be recompiled before completion. This number should be at or near zero, since recompiles can cause deadlocks and exclusive compile locks. This counters value should follow in proportion to Batch Requests/sec and SQL Compilations/sec. This needs to be nil in your system as much as possible.
Threshold: SQL Re-Compilations/sec < 10% of the number of SQL Compilations/sec

trigger_prototype.expression: ({Template Microsoft SQL Server DE Tier 1:perf_counter["\{#SQLINSTANCE}:Latches\Total Latch Wait Time (ms)"].avg(900,0)} / {Template Microsoft SQL Server DE Tier 1:perf_counter["\{#SQLINSTANCE}:Latches\Latch Waits/sec"].avg(900,0)})>0.1
trigger_prototype.name: SQL Instance {#SQLINSTANCENAME}: Total Latch Wait Time / Latch Waits/Sec avg value > 10% in the last 15 min
trigger_prototype.description:
Number of latch requests that could not be granted immediately and had to wait before being granted.
Latches are lightweight means of holding a very transient server resource, such as an address in memory.
Threshold: Total Latch Wait Time / Latch Waits Sec < 10

trigger_prototype.expression: {Template Microsoft SQL Server DE Tier 1:perf_counter["\{#SQLINSTANCE}:Access Methods\Workfiles Created/sec"].last(0)}>20
trigger_prototype.name: SQL Instance {#SQLINSTANCENAME}: Workfiles Created/sec {ITEM.LASTVALUE}
trigger_prototype.description:
Number of work files created per second. For example, work files could be used to store temporary results for hash joins and hash aggregates.
Threshold: high values can indicate thrash in tempdb and poorly coded queries.

trigger_prototype.expression: {Template Microsoft SQL Server DE Tier 1:perf_counter["\{#SQLINSTANCE}:Access Methods\Worktables Created/sec"].last(0)}>20
trigger_prototype.name: SQL Instance {#SQLINSTANCENAME}: Worktables Created/sec {ITEM.LASTVALUE}
trigger_prototype.description: Number of work tables created per second. For example, work tables could be used to store temporary results for query spool, LOB variables, XML variables, and cursors.
